_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A.    Describe the Accident Release Prevention and Emergency Policies



The Ziegenfelder Company, (herein referred to as "Ziegenfelder"), is a value-based organization where the well-being and protection of our employees, visitors, contractors, neighbors, and environment are woven into our daily decision making. The safe, reliable operation of our ammonia refrigerant is a top business imperative for the company. Ziegenfelder has and will continue to invest in the needed resources to prevent or minimize accidental releases of ammonia. This includes the investment in top talent; early detection, alarms, and automated shut-down devices; preventive maintenance; emergency response and preparedness; and, the training and development of employees to repair and maintain our covered process. 



Ziegenfelder's overarching Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) program is designed to reduce risk and drive improvement using the core principles of ISO 14001 and ISO 45001. This includes annual risk assessments, safe work procedures, training, emergency response plan, auditing, and monthly executive management reviews. In addition to common face to face communication platforms, the company leverages technology and social media to engage and empower the ~350 employees nationwide. Employees have a voice and the ability to raise issues through a phone application (VelocityEHS). The frontline leaders have the ability to enter work orders and help prioritize them through a computerized maintenance system (HIPPO).  Mobile equipment is equipped with InfoLink technology which ensures every lift is inspected before use while providing real-time driver behavior indicators such as speed, hard brake, and impacts. All of these procedures, processes and tools allow Ziegenfelder to develop corrective and preventative actions which specifically aid in the prevention of workforce injuries, ammonia releases, damaged equipment or products.  



When it comes to ammonia leaks, any odor of ammonia, mus

t be reported and logged into VelocityEHS for tracking and trending purposes. If ammonia has been detected or reported leaking, only members of the Special Maintenance Ammonia Response Tribe (SMART) are able to respond to the leak. The SMART members are trained and provided the needed protective gear and monitoring devices.



The company's senior leaders are ultimately accountable for the ongoing management of the process safety management (PSM) program, which is specifically designed to meet regulatory and best practices to ensure the safe use of ammonia in our business. These senior leaders include: Director of EHS; Vice President of Operations; Vice President of Engineering and Maintenance; and the Chief Executive Officer (CEO). Ziegenfelder has developed a Responsible, Accountable, Communication, and Informed (RACI) matrix to further ensure clarity across departments and positions. 



B.    Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



Ziegenfelder Wheeling, West Virginia manufactures flavored frozen ice treats and utilizes an ammonia refrigeration system. The facility stores anhydrous ammonia in excess of the threshold quantity outlined in ?68.10(a), and therefore is subject to the EPA's Risk Management Planning Rule and OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard. Ziegenfelder uses ammonia in a closed-loop refrigeration system. This system provides the operating processes for the main refrigeration system, which provides cooling for spaces; processing equipment; and frozen storage of finished product. Ammonia is the only regulated substances utilized at the facility.



C.    Description of the Accidental Release Prevention Program



The facility has a program level 3 accident release prevention program for the ammonia system that complies with EPA's RMP regulations and OSHA PSM. The ammonia prevention program consists of the following elements:



?    Employee Participation Program

?    Standard Operating Procedures

?    Process Hazard Analysis

?    Extraordinaril

y Hazardous Substance (Ammonia) Operator Training

?    Contractor and Contractor Employee Safety Program

?    Safety Reviews for New and Modified Ammonia Systems

?    Mechanical Integrity and Preventive Maintenance Program

?    Hot Work Permit Procedures

?    Management of Change Procedures

?    Ammonia Accident Investigation Procedures

?    Compliance Audit Procedures

?    Emergency Response Program



The policies and procedures for each of the elements above are controlled documents housed in an electronic central file system.



D.    Five-Year Accident History



During the past five years there has been one accident at the facility that resulted in a significant onsite or offsite consequence. 



On October 28, 2015, three employees received medical treatment following an ammonia vapor release from a ruptured pipe. Procedures related to maintenance activities and non-routine tasks were modified following this incident. In addition, upgrades were made to the mitigation system.

The Wheeling facility was not regulated by RMP at the time of this release because onsite storage was below 10,000 pounds.



E.    Description of the Emergency Response Program



An emergency response program has been implemented at the Wheeling facility. This program contains procedures describing how the facility will respond to fires, ammonia leaks and other emergencies, including evacuation procedures.



The emergency response program includes the following elements:



?    Emergency Response Events and Disasters

?    National Incident Management System (NIMS) Structure and Responses

?    Leak Response Procedure

?       Special Maintenance Ammonia Response Tribe (SMART) 

?    Training

?    Equipment

?    Limitations 

?    Alarm System and Emergency Evacuations

?    External Notification



Emergency response activities are coordinated with the Wheeling Fire Department.  Ziegenfelder has verbally contacted the department to review the most recent version of the Emergency Response Program and will be meeting with them

in June 2020, assuming the health concerns regarding the COVID-19 pandemic have been significantly reduced.  



F.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety



As the company continues to expand their ISO-modeled management system the following projects or changes are underway or planned over the next one and half years:



Goals and Objectives



1.    Integrate EHS performance indicators into the Operations dashboard (or similar) making data more readily available to leadership for quicker action when on or off target.



Training and Development



1.    Enhance New Employee Orientation to include additional safety topics. 

2.    Enhance training for new frontline leaders on their role and accountability for safe operations.

3.    Conduct investigation and root causes analysis (RCA) training to broaden problem-solving skills.

4.    Kickoff a Workforce Well-being Committee to further promote individual accountability and ownership for protecting one another, equipment, and product.

5.    Develop a positive project RCA program to root cause highly successful projects to repeat those actions/behaviors known to create success by choice, not chance.



Communication



1.    Increase the use of in plant TVs to help reinforce important safety messages.

2.    Transition to digital platform for safety alerts (e.g., 1-minute videos vs stagnant pieces of paper) to enhance the learning experience and better connect with the 5 generations of employees. 



Audit and Inspection



1.    Increase the frequency and rigor of facility safety and housekeeping inspections to continually drive improvement.
